title: This Spanish-Inspired Austin Home Is a Master Class in Mediterranean Modern
description: Designer Vanessa Alexander and architect Michael Imber blend styles and influences to craft a luxurious and easygoing family home
author: Jennifer Fernandez
excerpt: Designer Vanessa Alexander and architect Michael Imber blend styles and influences to craft a luxurious and easygoing family home
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.Like the state itself, the rolling plains of Texas Hill Country teem with Spanish Revival architecture, but it was the highlands of another famous place that provided more apt inspiration for a new construction family home in Austin that’s not your typical historical reboot.“Before this project started, I had spent some time in England seeing the work of Oliver Hill,” says San Antonio architect Michael G. Imber, who was impressed with the Arts and Crafts architect’s paean to the Alhambra at Marylands, the estate Hill built in Surrey in the 1930s. “His view of the Spanish Revival style is so different than we have here in the US. He had a fresh eye on the materiality and shape of the forms and masses.”That interpretation made plenty of sense in Austin, where the architecture skews more contemporary and less Mission inspired than in Imber’s home base of San Antonio. Working with interior designer Vanessa Alexander, of AD PRO Directory firm Alexander Design, and Dalgleish Construction Company, he conceived a U-shaped sequence of spaces that surround a central courtyard and feel as though they’ve been carved into the landscape, creating volumes both intimate and grand throughout the home. “It’s not about being ornamental,” Imber says of the gentle flow between indoor and outdoor spaces, which include a traditional belvedere that looks out over the city and beyond. “There’s a more humanistic, sculptural approach.”An interior courtyard landscaped by Jim Hyatt Studio marries the rugged stone of the Lake Austin surroundings with the cool modernity of the new structure and makes the outdoors an ever-present element in the house’s interiors. An antique limestone trough paired with climbing ivy imparts a sense of age. Accentuating a hand-wrought aesthetic was also the design intention of Alexander, who sought to soften and modernize some of the architecture’s classical interior elements to reflect the homeowners’ preference for a more relaxed lifestyle before construction even began. For her part, she looked to the simplicity of form in Puglia’s historic masseria and cave dwellings for inspiration. “There’s an authenticity in the context of these really weighty, hand-hewn materials that were not overly manipulated, allowing the space to breathe and be energetically light and youthful,” she explains.“The design reflected their desire to live beautifully but not ostentatiously,” says Alexander of the homeowners’ relaxed yet elevated aesthetic. In the living room, a mix of antique European and custom furnishings were clad in fabric by Kravet, Bruder, and Taktil to impart a feeling of sophisticated simplicity. Of the fireplace, Imber points to the “clean, somewhat austere plaster that’s been carefully sculpted.” The rug is from Mehraban, and the chandeliers are by Jonathan Browning Studios. Baseboard-free walls and unadorned arched entryways allow the streamlined plaster and reclaimed wire-brushed oak floors to establish a textural rhythm. Custom wood shelving and aged steel–cased windows nestle within niches, and alcoves—like the one that houses the marble-topped vanity in the primary bathroom—create moments of quiet emphasis. Doors are made of hand-tooled heartwood, while locally quarried limestone flooring was tumbled and honed to achieve a sense of age and depth. “It’s edited and spare but still has its roots in the familiar form and language of the area,” says Alexander.The furnishings underscore the warm minimalism on display in the architecture. In the living room, the graceful bentwood arms on a pair of vintage Art Deco–style chairs enhance the openness of the soaring, light-filled space, and the tactile, stone-hued fabrics used to cover other antique pieces channel the earthy landscape. The slim legs of the office’s burled wood desk mimic the filament-like casing of the arched window behind it, and understated lighting preserves the airy atmosphere. “I didn’t want to mess with the arches and all of those beautiful moments,” Alexander says of the delicate chain lines.Many of those moments revel in their juxtaposition of historic and modern, as in the powder room, where the iridescent light from a stained glass window softens the unfinished edge of the travertine sink and makes way for the loose playfulness of an asymmetrical mirror. It’s an intimate scene for an otherwise utilitarian space that perfectly captures the simple yet elegant ethos of the homeowners. “That’s them in a nutshell,” says Alexander. “It’s not overly opulent or showy. The interiors have a balance of elevated but approachable luxury that feels timeless.”Imber designed the house’s entry to feel like a sheltered, intimate scene that gives way to grander moments. The alabaster chandelier by Orphan Work maintains the elegant vaulted ceiling, and dappled light from tinted stained glass windows gently illuminates the moody space.The light sheen of the calacatta Monet marble countertops offset matte plaster walls in the kitchen. The pendants are by Rose Uniacke, the brass hardware is by Waterstone, and the art is by Tyler Guinn.Natural materials amplify the guest room’s connection to the landscape, as seen in the custom headboard upholstered in a cotton hemp by Kufri, Hawkins New York linen duvets on the beds, the Shoppe Amber Interiors bleached oak bedside tables, and hand-sewn wool kilim rug. The ceramic lamp is from Soho Home, and the artwork is by Tyler Guinn.A custom marble-topped oak vanity straddles the luxurious yet approachable aesthetic that defines the homeowners’ lifestyle. Wall-mounted brass taps by Studio Ore and sconces by Visual Comfort maintain the understated yet elevated sensibility. The pendant is by Felix Lighting Specialists.Reclaimed terracotta tiles, a custom travertine vanity, and creamy plaster walls provide a rustic foil for unlacquered brass hardware by Waterworks, Murano glass sconces from 1stDibs, and a pendant by McEwen Lighting.Alexander imbued another guest bedroom with cozy texture, incorporating a brutalist antique bench, a rattan pendant from Anthropologie, and a wool rug from Atacama Home. A wool blanket from Texidors and a vintage lounge chair add to the plush atmosphere. The BDDW bedside table is topped with an antique ceramic lamp.An outdoor stairway leads to the belvedere, an elevated pavilion with expansive views, where the family does yoga and entertains guests with sundowner cocktails. Custom lighting and handrails complete the space.An outdoor living room is sheltered under a vaulted ceiling of reclaimed wood. The custom dining table is paired with cane and teak chairs by Phantom Hands, each topped with a cushion clad in a Peter Dunham performance fabric. Steel barstools offset the lustrous zellige tiles in the kitchen area, which is lit by brass pendants from Lumfardo.The custom vanity coordinates with the limestone flooring in the pool bath, where a Rose Uniacke pendant hangs above an antique rug and bench and vintage Turkish pottery. The wall tile is from Villa Lagoon Tile, and the hardware is by Waterworks.The 1980s house that existed on the property was demolished to better position the new home for breathtaking vistas of the river and downtown Austin. The palazzo limestone flooring provides a neutral backdrop for custom daybeds covered in a Perennials by David Sutherland fabric. The pillows are clad in textiles by Zak + Fox and Peter Fasano.
html:
All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.

Like the state itself, the rolling plains of Texas Hill Country teem with Spanish Revival architecture, but it was the highlands of another famous place that provided more apt inspiration for a new construction family home in Austin that’s not your typical historical reboot.

“Before this project started, I had spent some time in England seeing the work of Oliver Hill,” says San Antonio architect Michael G. Imber, who was impressed with the Arts and Crafts architect’s paean to the Alhambra at Marylands, the estate Hill built in Surrey in the 1930s. “His view of the Spanish Revival style is so different than we have here in the US. He had a fresh eye on the materiality and shape of the forms and masses.”

That interpretation made plenty of sense in Austin, where the architecture skews more contemporary and less Mission inspired than in Imber’s home base of San Antonio. Working with interior designer Vanessa Alexander, of AD PRO Directory firm Alexander Design, and Dalgleish Construction Company, he conceived a U-shaped sequence of spaces that surround a central courtyard and feel as though they’ve been carved into the landscape, creating volumes both intimate and grand throughout the home. “It’s not about being ornamental,” Imber says of the gentle flow between indoor and outdoor spaces, which include a traditional belvedere that looks out over the city and beyond. “There’s a more humanistic, sculptural approach.”

Accentuating a hand-wrought aesthetic was also the design intention of Alexander, who sought to soften and modernize some of the architecture’s classical interior elements to reflect the homeowners’ preference for a more relaxed lifestyle before construction even began. For her part, she looked to the simplicity of form in Puglia’s historic masseria and cave dwellings for inspiration. “There’s an authenticity in the context of these really weighty, hand-hewn materials that were not overly manipulated, allowing the space to breathe and be energetically light and youthful,” she explains.

Baseboard-free walls and unadorned arched entryways allow the streamlined plaster and reclaimed wire-brushed oak floors to establish a textural rhythm. Custom wood shelving and aged steel–cased windows nestle within niches, and alcoves—like the one that houses the marble-topped vanity in the primary bathroom—create moments of quiet emphasis. Doors are made of hand-tooled heartwood, while locally quarried limestone flooring was tumbled and honed to achieve a sense of age and depth. “It’s edited and spare but still has its roots in the familiar form and language of the area,” says Alexander.

The furnishings underscore the warm minimalism on display in the architecture. In the living room, the graceful bentwood arms on a pair of vintage Art Deco–style chairs enhance the openness of the soaring, light-filled space, and the tactile, stone-hued fabrics used to cover other antique pieces channel the earthy landscape. The slim legs of the office’s burled wood desk mimic the filament-like casing of the arched window behind it, and understated lighting preserves the airy atmosphere. “I didn’t want to mess with the arches and all of those beautiful moments,” Alexander says of the delicate chain lines.

Many of those moments revel in their juxtaposition of historic and modern, as in the powder room, where the iridescent light from a stained glass window softens the unfinished edge of the travertine sink and makes way for the loose playfulness of an asymmetrical mirror. It’s an intimate scene for an otherwise utilitarian space that perfectly captures the simple yet elegant ethos of the homeowners. “That’s them in a nutshell,” says Alexander. “It’s not overly opulent or showy. The interiors have a balance of elevated but approachable luxury that feels timeless.”
